stem: A 34-year-old G3P2 client at 40 weeks gestation is in active labor. She suddenly screams, 'I’m going to die!' and becomes cyanotic. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute maternal collapse during labor.
Background: The client is a 34-year-old G3P2 at 40 weeks gestation with a healthy pregnancy. She has been experiencing strong contractions for the past 8 hours.
Assessment: At 14:30, the client suddenly screamed, 'I’m going to die!' and became cyanotic. Current vital signs show BP 58/30, HR 158 (weak/thready), RR 4 (agonal), and SpO2 62%. The client is pulseless. Bleeding is noted from the IV site and gums.
Recommendation: Initiate an immediate crash code. Prepare for an emergent perimortem Cesarean section (PMCS).

conditionOptions.text: Stable Transition to Second Stage Labor

actionOptions.text: Initiate high-quality CPR and provide 100% Oxygen (Intubation)
Prepare for an emergent Perimortem Cesarean Section (PMCS)
Massage the fundus vigorously to express clots
Administer STAT IV Oxytocin to speed up delivery

parameterOptions.text: Assess for bleeding from mucous membranes and puncture sites
Monitor Fibrinogen levels and coagulation markers (PT/INR/D-Dimer)
Assess for a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is an Amniotic Fluid Embolism (AFE) (Anaphylactoid Syndrome of Pregnancy) (c2). It is a rare but catastrophic emergency where amniotic fluid enters the maternal circulation, causing instant cardiopulmonary collapse and DIC (indicated by the low fibrinogen and bleeding gums/IV site). Priority #1 is resuscitation/intubation (a1). Priority #2, if the mother remains in arrest, is a Perimortem C-section (a2) to save both the fetus and improve maternal venous return. Monitoring focuses on the DIC (p1, p2).
clinicalPearls: The 'Sense of Impending Doom' is the classic subjective warning sign for AFE.
Most AFE cases involve a 'triad': Respiratory failure, cardiogenic shock, and coagulopathy (DIC).
DIC (bleeding from every hole) is seen in >80% of survivors/victims.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking fundal massage is the priority because the patient is bleeding.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Fundal massage is for ATONY (loss of muscle tone). The bleeding in AFE is DIC (failure of the blood to clot). Massage won't fix a lack of fibrinogen. Fix the oxygenation and blood factors.

mnemonic.title: AFE Crash
mnemonic.expansion: A-Agonal breathing. F-Fibrinogen low (DIC). E-Emergency C-section.
